questions.question: 1. What was the role of the semi-permeable membrane in the experiment?

answers.a: It allowed only water molecules to pass
answers.c: It allowed both water and salt to pass
answers.d: It increased the pressure on water

questions.question: What happened to the contaminants (like salt or dye) during the reverse osmosis process?v

answers.c: They broke down into pure water
answers.d: They were retained on one side of the membrane

questions.question: Why was pressure applied to the contaminated water side in the experiment?

answers.b: To push water through the membrane against natural osmosis

questions.question: In the simulation, increasing the applied pressure caused which of the following?

answers.c: Faster filtration and more purified water

questions.question: What direction did water move in the reverse osmosis experiment?

answers.a: From contaminated water side to the clean water side
answers.c: From the clean side to the dirty side
answers.d: From clean side to membrane only

questions.question: After performing the experiment, what can you conclude about the effectiveness of reverse osmosis?

answers.a: It increases the concentration of solutes
answers.b: It only works for solid contaminants
answers.c: It effectively removes contaminants using pressure and membrane
answers.d: It is not suitable for water purification

questions.question: If the membrane were damaged or missing, what would happen?

answers.d: Contaminants would pass freely to the clean side

questions.question: In your experiment, how did you measure the success of the reverse osmosis process?

answers.a: By checking clarity or solute concentration on both sides
